question.title: Will Donald Trump Jr. be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump Jr. is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, let's consider the current political landscape and the factors that could influence the selection of the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. Firstly, it's essential to note that the Republican Party's nomination process typically involves a combination of primary elections and caucuses, followed by the Republican National Convention, where delegates from each state gather to officially nominate their candidate. The nominee is usually the candidate who has secured the majority of the delegates during the primary elections and caucuses. Now, let's assess Donald Trump Jr.'s chances of becoming the Republican nominee. While he is the son of former President Donald Trump and has been involved in politics, he has not held any elected office and lacks significant political experience. However, he has been a prominent figure in the Republican Party and has built a strong following among some conservative groups. That being said, the Republican Party has a deep bench of potential candidates for the 2024 presidential election, including former Vice President Mike Pence, former Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, and several current and former governors and senators. Many of these individuals have more extensive political experience and stronger national profiles than Donald Trump Jr. Furthermore, while Donald Trump Jr. has been mentioned as a possible candidate, he has not yet announced his intention to run for the presidency. His father, former President Trump, has also hinted at potentially running again in 2024, which could significantly impact the nomination process. Considering these factors, it seems unlikely that Donald Trump Jr. will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. While he has some support within the party, he faces significant competition from more experienced and prominent candidates.

question.title: Will Ted Cruz be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?

This question will resolve as **Yes** if Ted Cruz is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Ted Cruz being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, let's consider several factors: 1. Previous Attempts and Experience: Ted Cruz ran for the presidency in 2016 and had a notable campaign, winning several primaries and caucuses. This experience could be beneficial if he decides to run again. 2. Current Political Landscape: The Republican Party's landscape is significantly influenced by figures like Donald Trump, who has hinted at running again in 2024. Trump's influence and potential candidacy could impact Cruz's chances. 3. Popularity and Support: Ted Cruz has a solid base of supporters within the Republican Party, particularly among conservative voters. However, his overall popularity and ability to attract a broader base of voters are concerns. 4. Fundraising and Campaign Infrastructure: The ability to raise funds and build a strong campaign infrastructure is crucial. Cruz has shown capability in this area in the past, but the competition in 2024 could be fierce. 5. Alternatives and Potential Opponents: The field of potential Republican candidates for 2024 is wide, including figures like Ron DeSantis, Nikki Haley, and others, in addition to Trump. The competition could dilute support for Cruz. Considering these factors, while Ted Cruz has a dedicated base of support and previous presidential campaign experience, the crowded and competitive nature of the Republican field, combined with the significant influence of Donald Trump, suggests that his path to the nomination is challenging.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Based on the strategic implications, the timing, and the resolution criteria, it seems unlikely that Joe Biden would make an announcement that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President before July 15, 2024.

question.title: Will Kamala's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Electoral College probability for Harris in Nate Silver's model is >46.6% on Friday August 9th at 8:40 PM. Resolves NO otherwise.

Link: https://www.natesilver.net/p/nate-silver-2024-president-election-polls-model

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, I'll need to consider the context and the factors that could influence Kamala Harris's odds of winning according to Nate Silver's model. First, let's establish a baseline: as of the creation date (July 2nd, 2024), Kamala Harris's Electoral College probability in Nate Silver's model is not provided, but we can infer that it's likely lower than 46.6% since the question implies an increase is possible. Over the next week, several factors could contribute to a change in her odds: 1. New Polls: If new polls are released showing Kamala Harris performing better than expected, her odds could increase. However, if the polls show her performing worse, her odds could decrease. 2. Campaign Events: Significant campaign events, such as debates, rallies, or endorsements, could positively or negatively impact her odds, depending on how they are received by the public and the media. 3. Opponent's Performance: If her opponents experience scandals, gaffes, or other negative events, Kamala Harris's odds could increase by comparison. 4. Economic or Political Developments: Major economic or political developments could influence voter sentiment and, consequently, her odds. Given the short timeframe (one week), it's unlikely that there will be a significant shift in her odds without a major event or a series of polls showing a substantial change in public opinion. However, the question only asks for an increase, not a major increase, and a small increase could be due to a variety of minor factors. Considering these factors, I would estimate that there's a moderate chance of her odds increasing, but it's far from certain.

question.title: Will Biden remain President through end of July 2024?
question.body:
Resolves YES if Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET); resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then.

Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendement (i.e. making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution)

metadata.chain_of_thought: Based on the current information available, President Biden's health, political stability, and the lack of significant legal challenges suggest he will remain President through the end of July 2024.

question.body: This question resolves YES if both of the following conditions are met: (a) There is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th, and (b) Joe Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET). It resolves NO if either condition is not met. Note that a temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment does not affect the resolution of condition (b).

metadata.chain_of_thought: Given the nature of the question, the probability of Joe Biden dying before the specified date is extremely low. This is particularly true considering that as of now, there have been no indications of any severe health issues that would lead to such an event. Additionally, the requirement that he remains President through the end of July 2024 adds further complexity, as it assumes a scenario where he would have to die and not be succeeded or incapacitated. Therefore, the likelihood of both conditions being met is very minimal.

question.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Joe Biden dies before Saturday, July 26th, 2024, or (b) Biden does not remain President through the end of July 2024?
question.body:
(a) Resolves YES if there is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th, 2024. Otherwise, resolves NO.

(b) Resolves YES if Biden does not remain US President through the end of July 2024 (ET). This includes if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then. Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment (i.e., making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution, as Acting President is different from President under the Constitution.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Considering the factors of health, political climate, and the specific criteria for resolution, while there are uncertainties, the likelihood of either event occurring before the specified dates seems low but not negligible.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Donald Trump being removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment as of July 15, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Legal Grounds: Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, also known as the Disqualification Clause, states that no person shall be a Senator or Representative in Congress, or elector of President and Vice President, or hold any office, civil or military, under the United States, or under any State, who, having previously taken an oath, as a member of Congress, or as an officer of the United States, or as a member of any State legislature, or as an executive or judicial officer of any State, to support the Constitution of the United States, shall have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the same, or given aid or comfort to the enemies thereof. But Congress may, by a vote of two-thirds of each House, remove such disability. 2. Application to Donald Trump: For this clause to apply to Donald Trump, it would need to be proven that he engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States, or gave aid or comfort to the enemies thereof, after having taken an oath to support the Constitution. The events of January 6, 2021, and Trump's actions and statements around that time could potentially be considered under this clause, but it would require a legal determination. 3. Legal Process and Timing: Any attempt to remove Trump from a ballot would likely involve court proceedings. Given the slow pace of the legal system, it's uncertain whether such a process could be completed by July 15, 2024, especially considering potential appeals. 4. Political Considerations: The decision to pursue removal under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment would also be influenced by political considerations. Given the polarized nature of U.S. politics, it's uncertain whether there would be sufficient political will to pursue such a course of action. 5. State Actions: The question specifies removal from the ballot of any U.S. state. Different states might have different approaches to this issue, and it's possible that some states might attempt to remove Trump while others do not. Given these considerations, while there is a theoretical basis for Donald Trump's removal from a primary election ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, the practical and political hurdles make it uncertain.

His popularity among a substantial segment of Republican voters remains high, which could be a strong factor in his favor. 2. **Current Political Climate**: The political landscape is highly polarized, with Trump remaining a central figure in Republican politics. While these factors could potentially impact his candidacy, Trump has historically shown resilience in the face of controversy. Considering these factors, while there are uncertainties and potential challenges, Trump's strong base within the Republican Party, his past success, and the current political climate suggest he has a significant chance of being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election.

question.title: Kamala president by Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to "Yes" if Vice President Kamala Harris is formally designated as President or Acting President of the United States at any point before July 26, 2024, 11:59 PM ET. Otherwise, this market will resolve to "No".

The primary resolution source for this market will be official information from the US government, however a consensus of credible reporting will also be used.

Resolver

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Kamala Harris being formally designated as President or Acting President of the United States before July 26, 2024, 11:59 PM ET, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current Political Context: As of my last update, there was no widely known or imminent plan for Vice President Kamala Harris to assume the presidency or acting presidency. The transition of power typically occurs due to the current president's inability to serve (due to resignation, incapacitation, or death) or at the end of a presidential term through election. 2. Health and Stability of the Current President: Without specific information on the health or stability of President Joe Biden as of the market's creation or resolution dates, we must assume that there are no publicly known immediate threats to his ability to serve. The president's health and well-being are closely monitored, and any significant concerns would likely be public knowledge. 3. Historical Precedents: The assumption of the presidency by the vice president outside of a regular election cycle is a rare event. It has happened a total of nine times in U.S. history, with the most recent instance being Gerald Ford's assumption of the presidency after Richard Nixon's resignation in 1974. These transitions are typically unexpected and occur under extraordinary circumstances. 4. Time Frame: The time frame provided (before July 26, 2024) is relatively short for an event of such magnitude to naturally occur without prior indication or expectation. Given these considerations, the likelihood of Kamala Harris being formally designated as President or Acting President before the specified date, without any current indication of such an event, is low. This assessment is based on the stability of the current administration, the lack of any publicly known plans for a transition, and the rarity of such events in U.S. history.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider two separate scenarios: (a) Donald Trump being removed from a primary ballot under the 14th Amendment, and (b) Ted Cruz being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. Regarding scenario (a), it's essential to understand the context of the 14th Amendment and its application. Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, also known as the Disqualification Clause, states that individuals who have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States, or given aid or comfort to its enemies, are ineligible to hold federal or state office. The clause was originally intended to prevent former Confederates from holding public office after the Civil War. In recent years, there have been discussions and debates about applying the 14th Amendment to individuals involved in the January 6, 2021, storming of the US Capitol or other activities deemed as insurrectionary. However, the process of removing someone from a primary ballot under the 14th Amendment is complex and would likely involve lengthy legal battles. Given the lack of clear precedent and the potential for protracted legal challenges, it's uncertain whether Donald Trump would be removed from a primary ballot under the 14th Amendment. However, considering the ongoing investigations and controversies surrounding Trump's actions, it's not impossible that some state or federal authority might attempt to invoke the 14th Amendment. Regarding scenario (b), Ted Cruz's chances of becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election depend on various factors, including the outcome of primary elections, party dynamics, and delegate selection. While Cruz has a dedicated base and has run for president before, the Republican field is likely to be crowded, and other candidates may have stronger support or more momentum. Assessing the probability of either scenario (a) or scenario (b) occurring is challenging, but based on current information and trends, I would estimate the probability as follows: Probability: 0.25. This estimate reflects a relatively low but non-negligible chance of either scenario occurring. The probability is not extremely low because there are ongoing investigations and controversies surrounding Trump, and Cruz has a dedicated base and previous experience running for president. However, the probability is not high because the process of removing someone from a primary ballot under the 14th Amendment is complex, and the Republican field is likely to be crowded, making it uncertain whether Cruz will emerge as the nominee.

Francis Suarez's Candidacy: Francis Suarez is the current Mayor of Miami, Florida. While he has been mentioned as a potential candidate for higher office, his national profile and political experience are not as extensive as some other potential candidates. His path to the nomination would require significant momentum and support from the Republican base, which is challenging given the crowded field of more established candidates. 3. Nikki Haley's Candidacy: Nikki Haley, a former Governor of South Carolina and the United States Ambassador to the United Nations under President Donald Trump, has a higher national profile and more political experience compared to Suarez. She has been considered a potential candidate for the Republican nomination in the past and has broader appeal within the party. However, she would still face stiff competition from other prominent candidates. 4. The Likelihood of Both Being Nominated: For both Suarez and Haley to be nominated, they would need to outcompete other candidates in the primaries and gain substantial support from the delegates at the Republican National Convention. The Republican Party often selects a presidential and vice-presidential candidate who complement each other in terms of political experience, geographical appeal, and ideological stance. While it's not impossible for two less traditional candidates to be nominated, the odds are against them, especially considering the competitive nature of the Republican primaries. 5. Historical Context and Party Dynamics: Historically, the Republican Party has often chosen nominees with significant political experience and national recognition. The dynamics within the party, including the influence of former President Trump and the factional divisions, could also impact the nomination process in unpredictable ways. Given these considerations, the probability of both Francis Suarez and Nikki Haley being selected as the Republican nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election is low. The competition within the party, the need for broad appeal, and the historical context of the nomination process all suggest that other candidates are more likely to secure the nominations.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question is asking whether at least 20 House/Senate Democrats will sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early. According to the context provided by Politico, dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party's effort to seal President Joe Biden's nomination sooner than originally planned. A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.), has been obtained by POLITICO, which offers the first public signal from Democrats that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden's candidacy. This suggests that there is already a significant amount of opposition to the plan within the Democratic Party. Additionally, the fact that multiple letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES increases the likelihood of the market resolving to YES. Given this information, it seems likely that at least 20 House/Senate Democrats will sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early.

question.title: Will INC form the government after the next Indian general election in 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if the INC has a member sworn in as the next Indian Prime Minister following the next general elections. All other parties will resolve as **No**.

This question will resolve for the next general election occurring after June 1, 2022 (currently expected for May 2024).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, let's consider the current Indian political landscape and the trends that could influence the outcome of the next general election. The Indian National Congress (INC) has been one of the dominant political parties in India since independence. However, in recent years, the party has faced significant challenges, including internal leadership issues, electoral losses, and the rise of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) as a formidable opponent. The BJP, led by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, has been in power since 2014 and has maintained a strong grip on national politics. Several factors will influence the outcome of the 2024 general election: 1. Current Political Trends: The BJP has been winning state elections and has shown resilience in maintaining its voter base. The INC, on the other hand, has struggled to regain lost ground. 2. Leadership: The INC's leadership, particularly Rahul Gandhi, has faced criticism for not being able to effectively counter the BJP's electoral strategies. The perception of leadership within the INC and its ability to inspire confidence among voters will be crucial. 3. Alliances and Coalitions: The formation of alliances and coalitions with regional parties could significantly impact the INC's chances. Successful alliances could help the INC gain more seats, but the party has had mixed results in managing such partnerships. 4. Economic and Social Issues: The state of the economy, unemployment, agricultural issues, and social harmony will influence voter sentiment. The INC will need to present a compelling vision to address these concerns to win over voters. 5. Campaign Strategy and Election Machinery: The effectiveness of the INC's campaign strategy, including its use of social media, grassroots mobilization, and the ability to counter the BJP's narrative, will play a significant role. Considering these factors, while the INC has the potential to improve its performance from the last election, the path to forming the government seems challenging. The INC would need to significantly reverse its recent electoral trends, improve its leadership perception, and successfully manage alliances to achieve this goal.

question.title: Will either INC or BJP form the government after the next Indian general election in 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either the INC or the BJP has a member sworn in as the next Indian Prime Minister following the next general elections. All other parties will resolve as **No**.

This question will resolve for the next general election occurring after June 1, 2022 (currently expected for May 2024).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, let's break down the key components and analyze them step by step: 1. Indian National Congress (INC) and Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) Dominance: Historically, the INC and BJP have been the two major parties dominating Indian politics. They have the largest voter bases, the most widespread organizational structures, and the most significant financial resources. This historical dominance suggests a high likelihood of one of these parties forming the government. 2. Current Political Landscape: As of the last update in 2022, the BJP, led by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, has been in power since 2014. The party has maintained a strong political presence and has a significant base of support. The INC, on the other hand, has been trying to regain its footing after losing power in 2014. Despite this, it remains the largest opposition party in the Lok Sabha (the lower house of the Indian Parliament). 3. Electoral System: India's electoral system is based on a first-past-the-post system for the Lok Sabha elections. This system tends to favor larger parties with broad appeal over smaller, regional parties. This further increases the likelihood of either the INC or BJP winning a majority or forming a coalition government. 4. Coalition Politics: Indian politics has seen a trend of coalition governments, especially when no single party achieves a clear majority. Both the INC and BJP have previously led coalition governments. Their ability to form alliances with other parties is crucial in a scenario where they don't achieve an outright majority. 5. Regional Parties: While regional parties play a significant role in their respective states, their influence at the national level is limited. However, they can be crucial in forming coalitions. The INC and BJP have historically been able to attract regional parties into their coalitions, further solidifying their chances of forming the government. 6. Public Sentiment and Campaigns: Public sentiment, campaign strategies, and leadership appeal can significantly influence election outcomes. However, predicting these factors far in advance is challenging. Both parties have shown the ability to mobilize large-scale campaigns and connect with their voter bases. Considering these factors, while there is a possibility of a third front or a coalition of smaller parties, the historical dominance, organizational strength, and coalition-building capabilities of the INC and BJP make it likely that one of them will form the government after the 2024 general election.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To determine the probability of Ted Cruz being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, let's consider several factors: 1. Fundraising and Campaign Infrastructure: Cruz has shown the ability to raise significant funds for his campaigns in the past, which is a crucial factor in the success of a presidential bid. However, the fundraising landscape can change, and other candidates might outperform him in this area. 5. Public Perception and Polls: Public perception of Cruz is divided, with strong supporters and detractors. His chances would depend on how he is perceived by the broader Republican electorate and whether he can attract new supporters beyond his current base. Considering these factors, while Ted Cruz has a dedicated base and significant experience, the competition for the Republican nomination is likely to be intense. question.title: Will OpenAI's ChatGPT be generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024?
question.body:
The question resolves as **YES** if [ChatGPT](chat.openai.com) is generally available in the EU on June 30, 2024, and **NO** otherwise.

"Generally available" here means that the default state for people in the EU is that they can access it without a VPN (possibly requiring paying for it.) "ChatGPT" here refers to the general web interface (not the API) for interacting with GPT models. Still resolves positively if the name or website has changed, as long as OpenAI's service is substantially the same (entering queries to systems based on Large Language Models).

question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Given the current situation, it seems that there is a possibility that a group of Democrats may come together to urge Biden to drop out, but it's difficult to predict whether this will happen before July 20th.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

question.title: Will Russia have control of Chasiv Yar on June 1, 2024?
question.body:

- Assessed Russian Advance in Ukraine

- Assessed Russian Gains in the Past 24 Hours

- Assessed Russian Control

- Claimed Russian Territory in Ukraine

- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Russian control of the location



The question will resolve as **No** if the location is not assessed to be in any of the categories indicating Russian control, which includes but is not limited to:



- Reported Ukrainian Territorial Gains in the Past 24 Hours

In other words the BoxOfficeMojo numbers should be seen as unofficial until there's confirmation in the Hollywood press. And the number we shoot for is >$284.5M internationally... this weekend

Part (b): Donald Trump is charged with witness tampering in Georgia before June 1, 2024. This part of the question pertains to the ongoing legal issues surrounding Donald Trump, specifically regarding allegations related to the 2020 presidential election in Georgia. The investigation led by Fulton County District Attorney Fani Willis has been looking into potential interference in the election, which includes allegations that could be construed as witness tampering. Given the legal complexities and the time it takes for such investigations to unfold, it's challenging to predict with certainty whether charges will be filed before a specific date. question.title: Will the Republican Party retain Ohio's 6th congressional district (previously held by Bill Johnson) in the 2024 special election?
question.body: This question will resolve as Yes if credible sources report that a person representing the Republican Party has won the special election for OH's 6th district. If popular sources are in disagreement, an Ohio State source or statement will be used. If no election is held before January 1, 2025, the question is annulled.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of the Republican Party retaining Ohio's 6th congressional district in the 2024 special election, we must consider several factors, including the district's historical voting patterns, the popularity and performance of the incumbent (or the incumbent party in this case, since Bill Johnson is not running), the strength of the Democratic challenger, and the overall political climate leading up to the election. 1. Historical Voting Patterns: Ohio's 6th congressional district has historically leaned Republican. Bill Johnson has held the seat since 2011, indicating a strong Republican presence in the district. 2. Incumbent Party Advantage: Even though Bill Johnson is not running, the incumbent party often has an advantage in elections due to name recognition, established campaign networks, and potentially more resources. However, this advantage can be less pronounced in special elections where turnout is typically lower and can be more unpredictable. 3. Democratic Challenger: The strength of the Democratic challenger plays a significant role. A strong candidate with good funding, a compelling message, and effective campaign machinery could pose a serious challenge to Republican retention of the seat. However, as of my last update, there's limited information on specific Democratic candidates and their potential impact. 4. Political Climate: The national and local political climate in 2024 could significantly influence the election. Issues such as the economy, healthcare, and any major events leading up to the election could sway voters. If there's a strong anti-Republican sentiment nationally, it could impact local races, including this one. 5. Special Election Dynamics: Special elections can have lower turnout, which might favor a party with a strong get-out-the-vote operation. Unpredictability is higher in these elections, as fewer voters participate. Given these considerations, the Republican Party has a historical advantage in the district and the benefits of being the incumbent party. However, the dynamics of special elections, the potential strength of a Democratic challenger, and the overall political climate introduce elements of uncertainty.

question.title: Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic nomination for President, and will the Republican Party retain Ohio's 6th congressional district in the 2024 special election?
question.body:
Will both of the following occur: (1) Joe Biden will announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President, and (2) the Republican Party will retain Ohio's 6th congressional district, previously held by Bill Johnson, in the 2024 special election?

Resolution criteria:

1. Joe Biden Announcement: This resolves as Yes if, prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement that he will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. The statement must be unambiguous and conclusive, leaving no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle. If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

2. Republican Party in Ohio's 6th District: This resolves as Yes if credible sources report that a person representing the Republican Party has won the special election for Ohio's 6th district. If popular sources are in disagreement, an Ohio State source or statement will be used. If no election is held before January 1, 2025, the question is annulled.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The combination of Joe Biden's likely continued candidacy and the unpredictability of special elections, despite the Republican lean of Ohio's 6th district, makes the joint occurrence of these events unlikely.

question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question requires a group of at least 5 named Democratic Party US House Members or US Senators to work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign or to urge him to do so before July 20th. While there are reports of some Democrats already urging Biden to drop out, these are individual efforts and do not meet the criteria of a group of at least 5 named individuals working together. However, the Politico report mentions that there are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats, with at least one draft calling on Biden to end his campaign. This suggests that there is a possibility of a group of Democrats coming together to urge Biden to drop out. Additionally, the fact that two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out and two endangered Democrats have written off his chances suggests that there is growing discontent within the party. Given the behind-the-scenes efforts and the growing discontent, it is possible that a group of at least 5 named Democrats may come together to urge Biden to drop out before July 20th.

question.title: Will Greece qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Greece participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If Greece does not qualify, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Greece qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, we need to consider several factors, including Greece's past performance in the contest, the current trends in music and voting patterns, and any changes to the contest format or rules that might affect qualification chances. Greece has a relatively strong history in the Eurovision Song Contest, including a win in 2005 with 'My Number One' by Helena Paparizou. Since the introduction of the semi-final format in 2004, Greece has consistently qualified for the final until 2016, when it failed to qualify for the first time. After that, Greece has had mixed results, qualifying in some years and not in others. This history suggests that while Greece has the potential to produce high-quality entries, qualification is not guaranteed. Eurovision voting patterns can be influenced by various factors, including cultural and geographical alliances, the quality of the song, and the performance on the night. Greece can often rely on votes from countries with significant Greek diaspora communities or those with cultural ties, such as Cyprus. However, the voting system and the increasing emphasis on the jury vote have made the contest more unpredictable. Any changes to the voting system, the way countries are allocated to semi-finals, or the rules regarding jury and public voting could impact a country's chances of qualifying. As of my last update, there were no announced changes that would significantly alter Greece's chances. Ultimately, the quality of the song and the artist's performance play a crucial role in qualification. Without knowing the specific entry for Greece in 2024, it's challenging to assess its potential for qualification accurately. Given these considerations, we can only make a general assessment based on historical data and trends. Greece has shown the ability to produce competitive entries, but the contest's nature means that qualification is never certain.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of a member of the Trump family being the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024, let's break down the key factors and individuals involved. 1. **Donald Trump**: As the 45th President of the United States and a member of the Republican Party, Donald Trump has a significant following within the party. His popularity among certain segments of the Republican base is high, and he has expressed interest in running for the presidency again. Given his previous success in securing the nomination and his continued influence within the party, he is a strong contender. 2. **Donald Trump Jr.**: While Donald Trump Jr. has been involved in politics and has a following, his likelihood of securing the Republican nomination is lower compared to his father. He lacks the same level of political experience and broad recognition. 3. **Eric Trump**: Similar to Donald Trump Jr., Eric Trump's involvement in politics is mostly through his family connections. He is less likely to secure the nomination due to his limited political experience and lower public profile. 4. **Ivanka Trump**: Ivanka Trump has had more formal involvement in politics, serving as an advisor to her father during his presidency. However, her appeal to the broader Republican base is uncertain, and her lack of elected office experience makes her a less likely candidate for the nomination. 5. **Tiffany Trump, Melania Trump, and Barron Trump**: These family members have less direct involvement in politics and are unlikely to be considered seriously for the Republican nomination. Considering these factors, the most likely scenario for a Trump family member to become the Republican nominee is through Donald Trump himself. The Republican Party's dynamics and the loyalty of a significant portion of its base to Trump make him a strong candidate for the nomination. However, the political landscape can change rapidly, and other potential candidates could emerge, challenging Trump's dominance within the party. Given these considerations, the probability of a Trump family member being the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024 is substantial but not guaranteed. The likelihood hinges primarily on Donald Trump's decision to run and his ability to maintain his base of support within the Republican Party.

Current Political Climate: As of my last update in 2022, the national political climate is polarized, with both parties experiencing various challenges and opportunities. However, Ohio's redistricting process and its impact on the 6th district would need to be specifically considered. 5. Special Election Dynamics: Special elections can have lower turnout and be more unpredictable than regular elections. Local issues and the candidates' ability to mobilize their base can play a significant role in the outcome. Given these considerations, and without more specific information on candidates, redistricting, and the current local political climate as of 2024, a general assessment leans towards the Republican Party retaining the seat due to the district's historical voting trends. However, special elections can be unpredictable, and many factors can influence the outcome.

question.title: Will 538 Project Biden as the favorite on Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50.

The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market.

This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

Please note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (eg. "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Given the lack of specific information on current trends and recent events that could influence the forecast, and acknowledging the inherent uncertainty in election forecasting, a well-calibrated forecaster would likely assign a probability that reflects a broad understanding of the election dynamics without overestimating the predictability of the outcome. Assuming no dramatic shifts in public opinion or significant events that would disproportionately favor one candidate over the other, one might lean towards a modestly optimistic outlook for Biden, given historical trends and assuming a stable economic and political environment. However, this is highly speculative without current data.

question.title: At the Paris Summer Olympics in 2024, will the men's 100m dash winning time break the Olympic record of 9.63s?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if any athlete runs the Men's 100M race at the 2024 Paris Summer Olympics in less than 9.63s, according to results posted by the [International Olympic Committee](https://olympics.com/en/olympic-games/olympic-results) or credible sources. If this does not happen, this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of the men's 100m dash winning time breaking the Olympic record of 9.63s at the Paris Summer Olympics in 2024, let's consider several key factors: 1. Historical Progression: The Olympic record in the men's 100m dash has progressively improved over the years, but at a slowing rate. The current record of 9.63s, set by Usain Bolt in 2012, has stood for over a decade, indicating a high benchmark. 2. Current Athlete Performance: As of the last available data before the creation of this question, several athletes have been performing close to the record, with some achieving sub-9.90s times. However, consistently breaking the 9.63s barrier is an exceptional feat that requires not just speed but also perfect race execution and conditions. 3. Advancements in Training and Technology: Improvements in training methods, sports science, and equipment technology can contribute to faster times. However, the men's 100m dash is a relatively simple event in terms of required equipment (primarily shoes and track surface), and while advancements can help, they might not be enough to significantly shave off times without a generational talent. 4. Competitive Environment: The Olympics provide the highest level of competition, where athletes often push themselves to new limits. The atmosphere and stakes can drive athletes to achieve record-breaking performances. Considering these factors, breaking the Olympic record requires a combination of exceptional talent, peak condition, optimal race execution, and perhaps a bit of luck with weather conditions. Given the long-standing nature of the current record and the rarity of athletes capable of challenging it, the likelihood of the record being broken seems relatively low but not impossible, especially considering the high level of competition expected at the Olympics.

Given the current geopolitical landscape and the fact that Russia, for example, has been competing under the Olympic flag in some sports due to doping sanctions, it's possible that Individual Neutral Athletes could win a significant number of gold medals. However, winning ≥15 gold medals would require a strong performance across multiple sports and events. For Individual Neutral Athletes winning ≥15 gold medals, I would estimate the probability as follows: Probability of Individual Neutral Athletes winning ≥15 gold medals: 0.1 (or 10%). However, winning ≥15 gold medals would require a strong performance across multiple sports and events. Considering these factors, the likelihood of Kamala Harris being the Democratic VP nominee again is high, primarily due to her current role, Biden's reelection bid, and the strategic advantages of maintaining consistency in the ticket.

question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

question.title: Will France place in the Top 5 at the 2024 Paris Olympics?
question.body:
This question will resolve positively if France place in the top 5 (ties resolve positively) at the Olympics being held in 2024. It will resolve ambiguously if the Olympics do not take place in 2024.

The medal table is calculated by taking the total number of medals won by each participating country and ordering by:

1. Number of Gold Medals
2. (Where 1 is tied) Number of Silver Medals
3. (Where 2 is tied) Number of Bronze Medal

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of France placing in the top 5 at the 2024 Paris Olympics, we need to consider several factors, including France's historical performance at the Olympics, the advantage of being the host country, and the competitive landscape of the games. Historically, France has been a strong performer at the Olympics. According to the Olympic Games' official website, France has consistently ranked among the top 10 nations in terms of total medals won since the 1992 Barcelona Olympics. In the 2016 Rio Olympics, France ranked 7th, and in the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, they ranked 8th. Being the host country can also provide an advantage. Host countries often invest heavily in their Olympic teams and infrastructure, which can lead to improved performance. Additionally, competing on home soil can give athletes a psychological boost. At the 2012 London Olympics, Great Britain, the host country, saw a significant improvement in their medal count, jumping from 51 medals in 2008 to 65 in 2012. However, the competition at the Olympics is fierce, and many countries have been improving their Olympic programs. The United States, China, Great Britain, and other top-performing countries will likely continue to be strong competitors. Considering these factors, I believe France has a good chance of placing in the top 5 at the 2024 Paris Olympics. They have a strong foundation of athletic talent, and the host country advantage could give them an edge.

question.title: Will GUE/NGL hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if GUE/NGL holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections and as **No** for all other political groups. If two groups are tied for seats, both will resolve as **Yes**.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The European United Left/Nordic Green Left (GUE/NGL) is a left-wing political group in the European Parliament. To assess the likelihood of GUE/NGL holding the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections, we need to consider the current composition of the European Parliament and the trends in European politics. As of the 2019 European Parliament elections, the GUE/NGL held around 5% of the total seats, which was significantly fewer than the two largest groups, the European People's Party (EPP) and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D), which together held over 50% of the seats. The 2024 elections are expected to see a shift in the balance of power, but it's unlikely that GUE/NGL will surpass both EPP and S&D to become the largest group. Moreover, the European Parliament has seen a rise in centrist and right-wing parties in recent years, which could further reduce the likelihood of GUE/NGL gaining the most seats. However, it's worth noting that the European Parliament elections often see low voter turnout, which can lead to unpredictable outcomes. Given these factors, it's unlikely that GUE/NGL will hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections.

question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

The polls and this question will never resolve N/A, and will remain open until the close time no matter what.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, let's break down the key components and analyze them step by step. 1. Understanding the Polls: There are two polls in question, both hosted on Manifold. One poll pits Donald Trump against Joe Biden, and the other pits Trump against a generic Democrat. The outcome we're interested in is whether Trump gains at least 3% more votes when facing a generic Democrat compared to facing Joe Biden specifically. 2. Public Opinion Trends: It's mentioned that public opinion polls show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but other Democrats either lead Trump or are within the margin of error in hypothetical matchups. This suggests a specific vulnerability or lack of enthusiasm for Biden that doesn't necessarily apply to other Democrats. 3. Representativeness of Manifold Respondents: The question of whether Manifold respondents are representative of the general public is crucial. If they are, we might expect their voting patterns to mirror those seen in broader public opinion polls. However, if they have a unique demographic or ideological skew, their responses might diverge from general trends. 4. Calculating Trump's Vote Share: The formula provided calculates Trump's vote share as a proportion of total votes cast for Trump, the Democrat (either Biden or generic), and 'Someone else.' The resolution criterion is whether Trump's share in the poll against a generic Democrat is at least 3% higher than his share in the poll against Biden. Given these considerations: - If Manifold respondents reflect broader public opinion trends, and those trends show Biden underperforming a generic Democrat against Trump, it's plausible that Trump could gain more votes against a generic Democrat. - However, the specific 3% threshold introduces some uncertainty. Polling margins can be tight, and a 3% difference is not trivial. It requires a clear and significant preference for Trump when facing a generic Democrat over Biden. Considering these factors, and acknowledging the inherent uncertainties in polling and respondent representativeness, my reasoning suggests a cautious optimism towards the resolution criterion being met, but with a significant degree of uncertainty.

question.title: Will Ireland qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Ireland participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If Ireland does not qualify, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Ireland qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, let's consider several factors: 1. Historical Performance: Ireland has a rich history in Eurovision, having won the contest a record seven times. However, their performance has been less consistent in recent years. Since the introduction of the semi-final format in 2004, Ireland has qualified for the final roughly half the time. This suggests that while they have the potential to do well, qualification is far from guaranteed. 2. Song and Artist Quality: The quality of the song and the performing artist can significantly impact a country's chances. Without knowing who will represent Ireland in 2024 and what their song will be, it's challenging to assess this factor accurately. However, Ireland has shown the ability to select competitive entries in the past. 3. Competition and Voting Patterns: Eurovision voting can be highly unpredictable and is influenced by a mix of song quality, performance, and geopolitical factors. Some countries tend to vote more consistently for others, but these patterns can change. The competition in the semi-finals, where countries are randomly allocated to perform, also plays a significant role. A strong performance can boost a country's chances, but the competition's quality can significantly impact qualification chances. 4. Recent Trends: In recent years, there has been a trend towards more contemporary and innovative entries doing well. If Ireland can select an entry that resonates with both the public and juries, their chances of qualification will increase. Given these factors, and without specific information about Ireland's entry for 2024, it's reasonable to approach this question with a cautious optimism based on Ireland's historical success but also acknowledging the unpredictability and competitive nature of Eurovision.

question.title: Kamala president by Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to "Yes" if Vice President Kamala Harris is formally designated as President or Acting President of the United States at any point before July 26, 2024, 11:59 PM ET. Otherwise, this market will resolve to "No".

The primary resolution source for this market will be official information from the US government, however a consensus of credible reporting will also be used.

Resolver

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, I'll consider the current political landscape, the line of presidential succession, and any potential factors that could lead to Vice President Kamala Harris being formally designated as President or Acting President of the United States before July 26, 2024. 1. Line of Succession: As Vice President, Kamala Harris is next in line for the presidency after President Joe Biden. This means that if anything were to happen to President Biden, such as resignation, incapacitation, or death, Vice President Harris would be next in line to assume the role of President or Acting President. 2. Health and Stability of President Biden: As of my last update, President Biden has shown no public indication of intending to resign and appears to be in relatively good health for his age. However, his age does increase the risk of health-related issues. 3. Impeachment or Removal: Another pathway for Vice President Harris to assume the presidency would be through the impeachment and removal of President Biden. This is a highly unlikely scenario given the current political makeup of Congress and the lack of any known grounds for such action. 4. Temporary Transfer of Power: In cases where the President is temporarily unable to discharge the duties of the office (such as during a medical procedure requiring anesthesia), the Vice President can take over as Acting President. However, these instances are typically planned and brief. Considering these factors, the most likely scenarios for Vice President Harris to become President or Acting President before July 26, 2024, involve unforeseen events related to President Biden's health or an unexpected political development leading to his resignation or removal. Given the information available and the general stability of U.S. political institutions, these scenarios are unlikely but not impossible.

The Nature of Political Campaigns: Political campaigns are fluid, and decisions can be made rapidly. However, a decision as significant as a presidential candidate dropping out would likely involve some preparatory work (like notifying key supporters, preparing a statement) that increases the chances of the story leaking. 5. Conditionality on Joe Biden Dropping Out: The question is predicated on Joe Biden actually dropping out, which is a significant condition. As of the last information available, there's no clear indication he plans to do so. However, if he were to drop out, it would be a monumental political event, increasing the likelihood that media outlets would be vigilant and quick to report any hints of such a decision. Considering these factors, it's reasonable to conclude that if Joe Biden were to drop out, the likelihood of a reliable media outlet getting wind of this and reporting it at least 6 hours in advance is quite high. Factors such as economic conditions, social issues, and international events can significantly influence voter preferences and, consequently, the composition of the government. Considering these factors, while the New Popular Front and Together coalitions are significant, the dynamic nature of French politics means there is a plausible chance that the Prime Minister could belong to a different coalition, especially given the time frame and the inherent unpredictability of political events.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, I'll consider several factors that might influence Joe Biden's decision to announce that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President in the 2024 election cycle before July 15, 2024. 1. Age and Health: Joe Biden's age and health could be significant factors. Born on November 20, 1942, he will be 81 years old by the 2024 election, making him one of the oldest presidential candidates in U.S. history. If health issues become more pronounced or if he feels that his age significantly impacts his ability to serve effectively, he might consider not running. 2. Approval Ratings and Public Support: The president's approval ratings and public support are crucial indicators of his potential success in an election. If Biden's ratings are low and public support wanes, especially among key Democratic constituencies, he might decide against seeking another term. 3. Economic and Political Landscape: The state of the economy, ongoing political trends, and significant events (domestic or international) could influence Biden's decision. A strong economy and favorable political landscape might encourage him to run, while a recession or significant political challenges might deter him. 4. Democratic Party Dynamics: The dynamics within the Democratic Party, including the emergence of potential challengers or shifts in party priorities, could also play a role. If the party seems to be moving in a direction that significantly differs from Biden's vision or if strong challengers emerge, he might choose not to run. 5. Personal Decision: Ultimately, the decision might come down to Biden's personal desire to serve another term. Factors such as his energy levels, his family's support, and his own sense of purpose and legacy could all influence this decision. Given these considerations, and without current data on Biden's health, approval ratings, or the political and economic landscape as of early 2024, it's challenging to make a definitive prediction. However, considering the age factor and the general political fatigue that often accompanies a president's second term, there's a plausible scenario where Biden might decide against seeking another term.

question.title: Will Chris Christie be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Chris Christie being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, let's consider several factors: 1. Current Political Landscape: As of my last update, Chris Christie, the former Governor of New Jersey, has been a significant figure in the Republican Party. However, his popularity and influence within the party have waxed and waned, particularly following his involvement in the Bridgegate scandal and his subsequent criticisms of Donald Trump. 2. Previous Presidential Runs: Christie has previously run for the Republican nomination in the 2016 presidential election but dropped out early in the race. This history might suggest a challenge in gaining widespread support within the party for another run. 3. Competition: The field for the 2024 Republican nomination is expected to be crowded, with several high-profile candidates potentially running, including Donald Trump, who has a significant base within the party. Other potential candidates might include Mike Pence, Ron DeSantis, and Nikki Haley, among others. The competition for the nomination will be fierce, making it challenging for Christie to stand out and secure the nomination. 4. Party Dynamics: The Republican Party's dynamics have shifted significantly since Christie's last run, with a greater emphasis on loyalty to Trump and his policies among a large segment of the party base. Christie's criticisms of Trump could make it difficult for him to win over Trump loyalists. 5. Fundraising and Support: Securing the nomination requires significant fundraising capabilities and support from major donors and party leaders. Christie's ability to attract these resources compared to other candidates is uncertain. Given these considerations, while Chris Christie has a certain level of recognition and experience, the challenges he faces in securing the Republican nomination for the 2024 US Presidential Election are substantial. The crowded field, the dynamics within the party, and his past performance in presidential politics suggest that his chances are relatively low compared to other potential candidates.

question.body:

Reasoning and Probability Summary: Given the analysis of both components of the question, the probability that both events occur—Trump gains at least 3% among Manifold respondents when facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, and Donald Trump testifies at the hush money trial—is estimated to be on the lower side due to the significant uncertainty and the generally unlikely nature of the second event.

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question requires the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet to invoke Section 4 of the 25th Amendment, declaring President Biden unable to discharge his duties. This is a rare and extraordinary measure that has never been invoked in U.S. history. The context provided mentions a GOP lawmaker asking Merrick Garland to invoke the 25th Amendment, but this is not a formal or credible step towards invocation. There is no public evidence to suggest that President Biden is unable to perform his duties, and no credible sources have indicated that the Vice President and Cabinet are considering invoking the 25th Amendment. Given the lack of evidence and the extraordinary nature of this event, it is highly unlikely that President Biden will be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024.
